bibl.title: Letter from George E. Armstrong to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1952

div1.p: Armstrong informs Hench he will be unable to attend the Camp Lazear dedication, but that he thinks Streit is a more appropriate representative anyway. Furthermore, Lawrence Reed, Blossom Reed and Truby will all be unable to attend as well. He mentions the possibility of financial assistance for representatives, but notes that aid for the memorial would require an act of Congress.

div1.head: Letter from George E. Armstrong to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1952
div1.opener:
DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE
DEPARTMENT OF THE ARMY
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON 25, D. C.
22 August 1952
IN REPLY REFER TO
MEDDA
619.3 (Camp Lezear) C
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
This is in reply to your four-page letter to me of 12 August which
concerned the coming dedication of certain memorials at the site of old
Camp Lazear in Cuba. General Love visited us just as your letter
arrived and we had a lengthy discussion of the problem with him.

I am inclosing a separate letter which was designed to be in such
form that you could make whatever use of it you deem desirable.

In this letter I shall touch on such of the points brought up in
your letters of 12 August as seem to solicit or warrant comment by me.
You will recognize, of course, that in many of the areas of interest
I can offer little more than my personal views or estimate of possi-
bilities.

I definitely share your views that it would be most desirable that
the United States Army be represented at the ceremonies and it is, of
course possible that such representation may serve to influence favor-
ably the decision of the Cuban Government as to the names to be accorded
to the memorials. I would be more than glad to attend personally, but
unfortunately my schedule is a heavy one during September, October and
November and includes trips outside of the Continental United States.
It, therefore, would seem to me unwise to attempt to commit myself to
attend the dedication, especially in view of the fact that its date is
somewhat uncertain. I have, however, a suggestion of a representative
who by nature of his position would be even more appropriate than
myself. Major General Paul H. Streit, who as you know is Commanding
General of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center and the Walter Reed Army
Hospital, can be made available in the event that an invitation is
forthcoming through the usual diplomatic channels. The fact that his
position and official title carry so prominently the name of Walter
Reed, it would seem to me that there might, thus, result gentle but
firm pressure which might influence the Cuban Government to give Walter
Reed's name equal prominence to that of Finlay.

Should an invitation be extended by the Cuban Government either
through the State Department or direct to me in my official capacity,
I shall be more than glad to nominate General Streit as my representative.

Concerning the possibility of Americans other than General Streit
attending the dedication, General Love tells me that he already has
contacted Major General Walter L. Reed and ascertained that it would be
impossible for the latter to attend. General Love also tells me that
General Truby has been in poor health and would be physically unable to
make the trip. He further feels that Walter Reed's daughter, Mrs.
Blossom Reed, is not in a position to attend. I have full confidence
in General Love's judgment in these cases.

I have been unable to obtain firsthand information as to the
physical status of Dr. Robert P. Cooke or Mr. James L. Hanberry, nor
do I know what their attitude would be should they receive an invitation
to attend the ceremonies.

I am inclosing herewith a list of the names of the American
volunteers who participated in the original experiments and who were
placed on the honor roll by act of Congress. In each instance I have
attempted to obtain full names including the middle name of each.
I have contacted in this connection the National Archives, the Veterans
Administration and the Adjutant General, but only the latter was able
to supply information which I have reason to believe is as complete as
may be had. I am assured that the names as recorded on the inclosure
are in exact accord with the Adjutant General's records and that where
no middle name appears, it is presumed that none was possessed or at
least none was recorded. I cannot obtain any satisfactory information
as to why John Bullard's name carries only a middle initial. Unfortu-
nately, I cannot be sure that this information will serve to clarify
your data, but at least it may be accepted as official from the stand-
point of the Department of the Army.

I have given very careful thought to the possibility of some
approach to the Cuban Government with reference to the name or names
to be memorialized. I have reached the conclusion that there is no
approach in my power which would assuredly avoid the possibility of
some resentment on the part of the Cubans. The same possibilities of
difficulties would exist whether I suggested an approach through the
State Department or through the Military Attache direct. It would
seem to me, therefore, that the personal contacts which you have
established in Cuba stand far more chance of bearing fruit than any
line of action within my capacities.

With reference to travel expenses for Americans attending the
ceremonies if invited, I probably can arrange for General Streit's
travel on Army orders and at the expense of the United States Army.
Limitations on the use of funds either under my personal control or
under that of the Secretary of the Army would seem to indicate it is
2
MEDDA
Dr. Hench
22 August 1952
impossible to assist in the case of any other of the individuals who
might be considered. There is, however, the possibility that the State
Department might consider it a good investment in Cuban-American rela-
tions to underwrite the expenses of some other representative or
representatives. This is purely a personal guess on my part and its
validity probably would rest on two factors: First, the nature of the
invitation extended by the Cuban Government, and secondly, the State
Department's present thinking regarding the desirability of making
special effort to cement goodwill of the Cuban Government.

I wish that it were possible for me to offer some helpful sugges-
tions regarding the provision of funds either for suitable inclosure
of the memorials or for future care, but I am unable to do so. Em-
ployment of official funds would not be possible except by special
act of Congress. Such act, of course, would require the active sponsor-
ship of a Senator of member of the House of Representatives.

I cannot close without expressing my admiration for the tremendous
amount of time and effort, to say nothing of expense, which you have
devoted to this project. If, of course, is unnecessary for me to say
how highly we in the Army regard any effort which serves to accord
proper recognition to the efforts of Walter Reed and his associates.
I hope that the obstacles which you have encountered will be overcome
and assure you that I shall stand ready at any time to do anything
within my power to be of assistance.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, GEORGE E. ARMSTRONG
Major General
The Surgeon General 2 Incls.
